prereq.p: 2. Download and Install Git on your computer.

context.p: If you want to work on your project on your local computer, you need to have Git installed. GitHub won’t work on your local computer if you don’t install Git.

Perform these steps to upload a file from a project folder on your computer to your GitHub repository. These steps need to be performed in the Git Bash or Windows Cmd window to add a file in your GitHub repository.

step.cmd: Setup gitHub to be used with Git on your computer.
Create your local Git project directory/folder on your computer.
Create your online repository using the + sign on the top left corner of your GitHub account page on the website.

Use git init command to initialize a new Git repository. Until you run this command inside a repository or directory, it’s just a regular folder. Only after you input this does it accept further Git commands.
Use git add command to bring new files to Git’s attention. After you add files, they’re included in Git’s “snapshots” of the repository.
Use git commit after you make any sort of change, to take a “snapshot” of the repository.
step.info: Usually it goes git commit -m “Message here.” The -m indicates that the following section of the command should be read as a message.

step.cmd: Use git push command to push the changes you made on your local computer to GitHub.

taskbody.result: Your local file is uploaded on your repository on GitHub.com. Your commits will be visible online on GitHub as well,
